Comment: White avoids c4, which allows me to play my Budapest. This move always left me with uninteresting choices (f5, b6, c5 - this last one very interesting, but again into very well-studied openings.

Here, plenty of possibilities. if Nc6-e5, everything holds. But black has the nasty Bf3 to play. So, the N has to jump away with check (otherwise, BxQ). Very nice was: Nf3-d5+. BxN (or the WQ is lost). Nc6xN+, but after QxN, there was nothing I could see. So I went for the "amazing"...
